get_population_distribution(e_id, mean, sd, log_mean, log_sd)[source]¶

get distribution for this population and exposure. e_id decides the distribution should be normal or lognormal or others

Parameters:
  • e_id (int) – exposure id
  • age_group (list) – age_group
  • mean (list) – mean
  • sd (list) – sd
  • log_mean (list) – log_mean
  • log_sd (list) – log_sd
  • m (int) – age group num
  • n (int) – measure num
Returns:

population distribution

get_attr_cc_exposure(index)[source]¶

get the i_th exposure in counterfactual compound exposures list, all exposures mortalities are the compound results of all previous exposures. The mortality of the first exposure is the same as baseline only exposure mortality

Parameters:index (int) – index of exposure
Returns:the indexth exposure, an PrimeExposure object
Raises:index out of bound error
get_attr_exposure_outcome_death_gender(index, o_id)[source]¶

get ith exposure o_id th death from new counterfactual exposures

Parameters:
  • index (int) – index of exposure
  • o_id – outcome id, the same id as in the database
  • is_male (bool) – gender
  • is_baseline (bool) – is baleline or counterfactual
Returns:

[b_m,b_f,c_m,c_f]death sum for a specific exposure and outcome

get_dist_type(e_id)[source]¶

get distribution type for exposure according to its id

Parameters:e_id (int) – exposure id, should be the same id as in the database
Returns:distribution type for this exposure
get_exposure(exposure_id, b_mean, b_sd, c_mean, c_sd, non_rate, dist_type, mortalities)[source]¶

This function initiate an exposure object

Parameters:
  • exposure_id (int) – id for exposures
  • b_mean (array) – mean for baseline
  • b_sd (array) – standard deviation for counterfactual
  • c_mean (array) – mean for baseline
  • c_sd (array) – standard deviation for counterfactual
  • non_rate (array) – non rate for smokers/drinkers
  • dist_type (int) – distribution type 0: normal distribution; 1: lognormal distribution; 2: binary distribution
  • mortalities (dict) – baseline mortalities for a new exposure, could be mortality in db or counterfactual mortality of previous exposure, {outcome_id:[mortalities of current outcome]}
Returns:

an exposure object
Raises:

an exception
get_exposure_list(e_list)[source]¶

This function, could be compound result or ‘only’ result, take salf for example:

Parameters:e_list (list) – a list for exposures, if list is [4], then it is only sheet; if list is [1,2,3,4], then it is none sheet
Returns:a list of initial/baseline exposures
get_exposure_outcome_death_age(a_id, exposure)[source]¶

get deaths sum for a_id age group in exposure, this age group id (a_id) should be a valid id for exposure, otherwise it raises NotFound or IndexOutOfBound error

Parameters:
  • a_id (int) – age group id
  • exposure (an PrimeExposure object) – exposure to get data
Returns:

deaths sum for a_id age group
get_initial_exposures()[source]¶

get the initial baseline and counterfactual exposures,*be called only once when the program started*, only_exposures keeps the same in the whole process, while cc_exposures changes with new parameters

Parameters:self – self attrubtes
Returns:a list of initial/baseline exposures

output_counterfactual_mortality_num = []¶
output_counterfactual_mortality_total = 0¶
read_json(fileaddress)[source]¶

read json from fileaddress and store the content into exposures global variables, the json file format should look like [{u’non_rate’: 25, u’e_id’: 1, u’sd’: 25, u’mean’: 15.6}, {u’non_rate’: 100, u’e_id’: 2, u’sd’: 25, u’mean’: 3.6}]

Parameters:fileaddress (string) – A string to be converted
Returns:json content
refresh_output_baseline_mortality()[source]¶

refresh final baseline compound mortality for output, it should be the baseline mortality of the intial exposure

Parameters:self – self attrubtes
Returns:No return
refresh_output_counterfactual_mortality()[source]¶

refresh final compound mortality for output, it should be the counterfactual mortality of the final exposure

Parameters:self – self attrubtes
Returns:No return

get_baseline_death_rate(base_mortality, population_distribution_line, relative_risks_line)[source]¶

This function returns the baseline death rate for death rates calculation, in each row, all other rates are relying on this base rate

Parameters:
  • base_mortality (list) – base mortality, either from baseline data [only exposures] or from previous exposure result [compound]
  • population_distribution_line (list) – the relavent line in population distribution
  • relative_risks_line (list) – the relavent line in relative risk
Returns:
get_c_mortality()[source]¶

calculate counterfactual mortalities

Parameters:self – self attributes
Returns:No return
get_death_rates(population_distribution)[source]¶

This function starts the calculation of death rates for a subset, it does not necessarily need to care what subset it is dealing with

Parameters:
  • mortality (list) – original mortality
  • population_distribution (list) – this calculation needs population distribution, matrix or line if there is only one population subset
  • relative_risks (list) – relative risks from last step
Returns:
get_deaths(b_population_distribution, c_population_distribution)[source]¶

This function starts calculating deaths for a subset data, without concering baseline or counterfactual,

Parameters:
  • population_distribution (list) – the relavent population distribution
  • death_rates (list) – death rates
Returns:

No return

Parameters:self – self attributes

linear_relative_risk_decrease(i, j, lower_limit)[source]¶

This function calculation relative risk value for linear distribution in a decrease case, in which relative risk decreases as consumption decreases

Parameters:
  • i (int) – row number
  • j (int) – column number
  • lower_limit (int) – lower limit of current exposure
Returns:

current relative risk value
linear_relative_risk_increase(i, j, lower_limit)[source]¶

This function calculation relative risk value for linear distribution in an increase case, in which relative risk decreases as consumption increases

Parameters:
  • i (int) – row number
  • j (int) – column number
  • lower_limit (int) – lower limit of current exposure
Returns:

current relative risk value

Parameters:mortalites – original mortalities

:parameters for different types of fats, these display correllation between different types of fats

primemodel.logic.get_population_density(size, upper, lower, mean, sd, log_mean, log_sd, dist_type, is_last)[source]¶

This :returns a value of a population distribution

Parameters:
  • size (float) – total size
  • upper (float) – upper value of bin
  • lower (float) – lower value of bin
  • mean (float) – mean
  • log_mean (float) – log mean
  • sd (float) – standard deviation
  • log_sd (float) – log standard deviation
  • dist_type (int) – distribution type, normal, log or binary
  • is_last (bool) – is the last bin of samples or not
Returns:

population density
